poem:
Title: "Vaccination Lament"

Small demons of infection rise,
In merry England's rolling guise;
Unseen villain measles flies.
Nervy shadows raise the dread,
Health's trust now hangs by throbbing thread.
Look, see our falling shield instead,
Nurse thy needle, stead thy aim,
Vaccinate, to quell this flame. 
A plea, spun in the poet's frame:
Sing the lore of trust regained,
Speak of illness humbly chained,
England's healthful reign sustained.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "UK measles outbreaks: why are cases rising and vaccination rates falling? With outbreaks of measles occurring across England and Wales, we take a look at what is behind the rise, and what must be done to stop it. What is measles? Measles is a highly infectious virus that can cause serious illness, such as inflammation of the brain. Related: Surge in measles cases prompts UK to declare national health incident “Even in high-income countries like". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
